results.title: Murray River quest
results.brief_description: This is the story of Australia’s greatest river seen through the eyes of two canoeists on an expedition seeking the history of the river and it’s importance in the development of Victoria and New South Wales. It tells of First Nations peoples, explorers and town founders; of irrigators, woodcutters and fishermen - all those people whose lives and adventures make up the history of the Murray River.

results.title: Frontier: stories from white Australia's forgotten war: part one: they must always consider us as enemies 1788-1830
results.brief_description: Soldier/Administrator David Collins, arriving in Sydney on the First Fleet is acknowledged as being the first official to acknowledge there is tension between blacks and whites in their struggle over the land. Fighting ends temporarily in Tasmania after a verbal treaty is reached acknowledging partial rights over the land to First Nations peoples. The Government quickly breaks this verbal promise however and First Nations people flee into exile.

results.title: Frontier: stories from white Australia's forgotten war: Part two: worse than slavery itself 1830-1860
results.brief_description: Humanitarians and missionaries begin an anti slavery plight on behalf of First Nations people against the Crown. Despite their efforts however and a growth in national awareness, the massacres continue.

results.title: Frontier: stories from white Australia's forgotten war: part three: the government should shut its eyes 1860-1938
results.brief_description: The final part in the ‘Frontier’ series moves North to Queensland where First Nations peoples resistance is high. An estimated ten thousand First Nations people lose their lives in the resistance with the law of the day, the Colonial Government, seemingly turning a blind eye. In the face of these massacres, forced assimilation and breeding out, First Nations people started to organise politically and informed white Australia they had no intention of dying out.

results.title: Understanding Wik
results.brief_description: The High Court’s Wik and the subsequent action by the government to, as the PM said, restore the pendulum, has caused great division in the Australian community. Unfortunately, much of the heat in the debate has been caused by ignorance and widespread lack of understanding of Wik Peoples’ case. In this high quality video, the basics of the Wik Decision and the federal government’s answer: the now infamous 10 Point Plan and the legislation introduced into parliament late in 1997 are explained simply and concisely. Suitable for Middle Secondary to Tertiary level students.

results.title: Namatjira the painter
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes, Ralph Foster and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The story of Albert Namatjira, who once worked as a cook and camel-boy for the landscape painter Rex Batterbee. Namatjira became interested in painting and under Batterbee’s tuition, began to use watercolours to reproduce on canvas the Central Australian landscape. This vintage film, made at the height of Namatjira’s popularity shows the painter at work and discusses the influence of the environment on his beautiful original landscapes. Rich with illustrations of his work, this film is a tribute to the painter.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stanley Hawes, Ralph Foster and Australian National Film Board

results.title: The Art of tracking
results.creator_credit: Gary Steer, Tina Dalton, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Discovery Communications, Sky Visuals, Telecast and Wild Visuals
results.brief_description: Although the art of tracking is diminishing worldwide, the skill survives and traditionalists are making efforts to revive it. There are pockets of indigenous people who still rely on their skills to hunt animals for their livelihood. Amongst First Nations peoples in arid Australia, the Kalahari Bushmen of Africa and the Inuit of the Arctic, the ability to read the earth survives. This program examines the skills of these people from vastly different environments and is the story of the skill not the kill; the story of “nature detectives”. Awarded the Certificate for creative excellence, USA International Film and Video Festival 1997.

results.title: Australian aborigines: living off the land
results.creator_credit: A.P. Elkin and A I F
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Taken during the University of Sydney’s 1952 expedition to Arnhem Land, this film shows local people living off the land and its resources.

results.title: Australian Aborigines: everything from nature
results.creator_credit: A.P. Elkin and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Our reliance on manufactured goods is contrasted with First Nations peoples’ abilities to use natural materials around them, which gives rise to a marked respect for their adaptability and sensitivity to the environment. Taken during an expedition by Sydney University to Arnhem Land in 1952.

results.title: My life
results.creator_credit: Bruce Joel Rubin, Hunt Lowry, Jerry Zucker and Capella International
results.brief_description: Bob Jones (Michael Keaton) is an ordinary man dying of cancer. As a legacy to his unborn child, he attempts to make a video of his life as he perceives it. It is only when he is confronted with the artifice of his own existence that he becomes determined to come to grips not only with the past, but with the disease. Embarking on a new lifestyle and rigid self-examination, and aided by Mr Ho, a spiritual healer, Bob undertakes a voyage of self-discovery. Nicole Kidman stars as Gail Jones, and Dr. Haing S. Ngor as Mr. Ho. Unashamedly a tear-jerker, “My life” is a compelling and sentimental drama, which emphasises the dignity of the dying and the need to embrace life. Truly vomitous.
